title: 108_hr4550
content: The Act is titled the "Safe, Efficient, Coordinated, Unified, Revitalized, Enhanced Visa Waiver Act" and requires electronic submission of biographical information by visa waiver participants. The Secretary of Homeland Security must establish an electronic system for visa waiver program participants to submit biographical information before entering the United States. The system must provide an electronic response within 30 minutes to determine the eligibility of the alien for admission as a nonimmigrant visitor. The electronic system must provide a response within 30 minutes to determine the eligibility of an alien for admission as a nonimmigrant visitor. Carriers and corporations must inquire electronically about the alien's eligibility before embarkation, with a response time of 90 seconds or less. The system deployment should occur promptly after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security will establish a fee for aliens seeking admission, ensuring full cost recovery. Consultation with a private sector group is required for system development. Deployment of the system should happen promptly after the Act's enactment. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act requires the installation of equipment and software at all ports of entry into the United States for biometric comparison and authentication of visas, travel documents, and passports by specific deadlines. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act mandates the implementation deadline for technology standards to be extended to 2005. Additionally, a limited good faith waiver is introduced. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act mandates extending technology standards deadline to 2005 and introduces a limited good faith waiver allowing the Secretary of Homeland Security to grant extensions for countries making progress towards meeting passport requirements. The Secretary of Homeland Security considers factors like country's efforts to meet passport requirements by specific deadlines and pilot programs for issuing compliant passports when determining substantial progress. The Secretary of State certifies these factors. Passports meeting requirements will be issued before March 26, 2006. Reports on countries' progress are due by October 26, 2005, and a final report by April 25, 2006. Section 303 of the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act is amended to replace "Attorney General" with "Secretary of Homeland Security."
